subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Correct.  To make things worse, Australian ice does not quite rhyme with American/British choice ; it is pronounced somewhat lower and further forward
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> Good! I mean, now I think we have a very concrete example to go by. For
> the word "buy" you say use "Ice," and I think Anthony says use "Ice" if
> you are an American, but use "Oy" if you are Australian.

Correct. To make things worse, Australian "ice" does not quite rhyme with
American/British "choice"; it is pronounced somewhat lower and further
forward in the mouth. This is a diphthong that Northern Hemisphere
accents don't have, and it sounds like "oi" to most of us -- but if you
listen to an Australian saying "buy" and "boy", you can hear that they
are different.

--
Yes, chili in the eye is bad, but so is your John Cowan
ear. However, I would suggest you wash your cowan@...
hands thoroughly before going to the toilet. http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
--gadicath

> Good! I mean, now I think we have a very concrete example to go by. For 
> the word "buy" you say use "Ice," and I think Anthony says use "Ice" if

American/British "choice"; it is pronounced somewhat lower and further
forward in the mouth.  This is a diphthong that Northern Hemisphere
accents don't have, and it sounds like "oi" to most of us -- but if you
listen to an Australian saying "buy" and "boy", you can hear that they
are different.
